document.docAuthor: Bassini-Silva, R. & Zampaulo, R. A. & Welbourn, C. & Ochoa, R. & Brescovit, A. D. & Barros-Battesti, D. M. & Jacinavicius, F. C.
document.docTitle: A new genus and two new species of chigger mites (Trombidiformes: Leeuwenhoekiidae) from Brazilian caves with notes about the genus Whartonia Ewing, 1944

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new genus and two new species of chigger mites (Trombidiformes: Leeuwenhoekiidae) from Brazilian caves with notes about the genus Whartonia Ewing, 1944

emphasis.docTitle:
A new genus and two new species of chigger mites ( Trombidiformes : Leeuwenhoekiidae ) from Brazilian caves with notes about the genus
Whartonia Ewing, 1944

subSection.paragraph: R. Bassini-Silva a,b , R. A. Zampaulo c , C. Welbourn d , R. Ochoa e , A. D. Brescovit a,f , D. M. Barros-Battesti b and F. C. Jacinavicius a aLaboratório de Coleções Zoológicas, Instituto Butantan, São Paulo , Brazil ; bDepartamento de Patologia, Reprodução e Saúde Única, Faculdade de Ciências Agrárias e Veterinárias –UNESP, Jaboticabal, Brazil ; cGerência de Licenciamento Ambiental e Espeleologia, Vale SA, Nova Lima, Brazil ; dNational Insect and Mite Collection, Smithsonian Institution, National Museum of Natural History, Washington , DC, USA ; eSystematic Entomology Laboratory, United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Beltsville, MD, USA ; fDepartamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Biociências – USP, São Paulo , Brasil

document.paragraph:
ABSTRACT The family Leeuwenhoekiidae has a worldwide distribution. In Brazil , it is represented by five genera and 10 species parasitising all groups of terrestrial vertebrates. Examination of material housed in the Acari Collection of the Instituto Butantan revealed undescribed species belonging to this family. In the present study, we describe a new genus,
Caramuruacarus
gen. nov. , with the type species
Caramuruacarus carnavalesca
sp. nov. from the Minas Gerais State and a new species for the genus
Whartonia
,
Whartonia parauapebensis
sp. nov. , from Pará State , both from the soil of Brazilian caves. In addition, a discussion of the genus
Whartonia
and its subgenera is provided.

http://www.zoobank.org/

http://www.zoobank.org/

paragraph.subSection: ARTICLE HISTORY Received 30 May 2022 Accepted 22 August 2022

subSection.paragraph:
chigger; ectoparasite; caves; Acari ; new genus; new species
Introduction
The family Leeuwenhoekiidae Womersley, 1944 ( Acari : Trombidiformes ) has a worldwide distribution, and in Brazil is represented by 10 species in five genera. These species are:
Apolonia tigipioensis Torres and Braga, 1938
;
Hannemania aiuabensis Bassini-Silva, Jacinavicius and Welbourn, 2021
;
H. hepatica Fonseca, 1936
;
H. hylodeus (Oudemans, 1910)
;
H. newsteadi Sambon, 1928
;
H. stephensi Sambon, 1928
;
Leeuwenhoekia verduni (Oudemans, 1910)
;
Paraguacarus klompeni Jacinavicius and Bassini-Silva, 2021
;
Whartonia nudosetosa ( Wharton, 1938 )
and
W. pachywhartoni Vercammen-Grandjean, 1966
( Jacinavicius et al. 2018a , 2021; Bassini-Silva et al. 2021c ). Of these species, only
Whartonia nudosetosa
and
W. pachywhartoni
were collected from cave-dwelling bats.
Whartonia nudosetosa
was originally described from Mexico ( Wharton 1938 );
W. nudosetosa
from Brazil were collected in Minas Gerais State , on Seba’s short-tailed bat,
Carollia perspicillata
(L.) ( Chiroptera : Phyllostomidae ) ( Silveira et al. 2015 ).
Whartonia pachywhartoni
was described parasitising the little big-eared bat,
Micronycteris megalotis (Gray, 1842)
and reported from
C. perspicillata
( Chiroptera : Phyllostomidae ) in Minas Gerais State ( Vercammen-Grandjean 1966 ; Silveira et al. 2015 ).
The behaviour and habitat of these species are not well understood. In the present study, we describe a new genus and two new species of the family Leeuwenhoekiidae collected from the soil of Brazilian caves.

The collections were made in 2009 in Pará State and in 2013 additional collections were made in Minas Gerais State by the staff of Carste Ciência e Meio Ambiente. These collections were intended for the study of a community of cave-dwelling arthropods, and several invertebrates were collected. Subsequently, the data from these collections will also be used for environmental licensing studies. In general, the invertebrates were collected manually with the aid of tweezers and brushes through the active search method. No auxiliary equipment was used to extract or visualise the invertebrates (including mites) in the field. The caves were inspected along their entire length, and micro-habitats – spaces under rocks, in crevices and accessible channels, on ceilings and walls and places with higher humidity – were prioritised. The collection time was determined as a function of its complexity, this being the result of the sampling effort with the greatest possible degree of detail. All organisms collected were preserved in 70% alcohol. In the laboratory, after sorting the material, the mites were sent for identification to the Acarological Collection of the Butantan Institute ( IBSP ), São Paulo , Brazil .

The mites described in the present study were collected from two Brazilian caves, these caves are briefly described below, according to technical licensing reports from Carste Ciência e Meio Ambiente (2010, 2014). These licensing reports are not available to the public. Therefore, we summarise from these technical reports the main information on both caves.

Cave CH _0025 ( Figure 1 (a)) is located in Ouro Preto Municipality, Minas Gerais, at 1457 masl , near the Serra de Capanema, the Quadrilátero Ferrífero (Iron Quadrangle). This cave is a small cavity within iron formation rocks, comprising a small room without aphotic zones. The cave extends 6.4 metres horizontally and was 2.5 metres high, covering 21 m 2 , 11 m
3 in
volume and without a dark zone. The floor consists of fine sediments with gravel and boulders in the entry region, and fine sediments with roots in the twilight zone. Litter deposits were observed near the entrance.

Cave N3_0047 ( Figure 1 (b)) is in Carajás National Forest, Parauapebas Municipality, Pará State , at 473 masl . The caves are located in a complex iron ore outcrop. There are different litho-types in the region, with caves associated to the superficial ferruginous breccia (canga formation), to the iron ore and to ferricretes. In total, this cave complex extends 182 metres horizontally into the dark zone and is 3.41 high, covering 118 m
2 in
area and 195 m
3 in
volume. The floor of the cave had litter, roots, guano and other debris.

caption.paragraph: Figure 1. General view of the collection sites. (a) Cave entrance (CH_0025) situated in Minas Gerais State; (b) cave (N3_0047) situated in Pará State.

heading.emphasis: Preparation and identification of the material

subSection.paragraph: Specimens were slide-mounted in Hoyer’s medium following the protocols described by Walter and Krantz (2009) and compared at the genus level using the Neotropical and Nearctic keys published by Brennan and Goff (1977) . In addition, the specimens were described by comparing them to the original descriptions and subsequent redescriptions of related species.

Morphological characters were examined and measurements were made using a Leica DFC 500 digital camera coupled to a Leica DM4000B phase contrast optical microscope. Extended focal range images were composed using Leica Application Suite v. 2.5.0. The images were prepared with Adobe Photoshop v. 13.0 and Inkscape v. 1.0.1.

We used the nomenclature created by Grandjean (1939) with adaptations by Kethley (1990) for the dorsal opisthosomal setae and setae on the prodorsal, and Grandjean (1935 , 1947 ) for the specialised setae on the legs and palps. Additional nomenclature was based on the glossary proposed by Goff et al. (1982) .
All the specimens examined were deposited in the IBSP (curator: V .C. Onofrio). The measurements are given in micrometres ( Tables 1–4 ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Larva. Palptarsus with five-branched setae and solenidion (ω) ( Figure 2 (a,b)); odontus tetrafurcate ( Figure 2 (a)); cheliceral blade with tricuspid cap and the dorsal side with row of teeth ( Figure 2 (a)); eyes present, 2/2 ( Figure 3 ); tracheae and stigma absent; prodorsal sclerite with nasus ( Figures 3 , 10 (a)); pair of flagelliform trichobothria ( si ) ( Figure 3 ); se setae on prodorsal sclerite ( Figures 3 , 10 (a)); Fe legs I–III each entire ( Figure 5 ); Cx I bisetose ( Figure 5 (a)); Cx II and III each unisetose ( Figure 5 (b,c)); pretarsus legs I–III each with claws and claw-like empodium without onychotriches ( Figure 5 ); Ge I with two solenidia (σ) ( Figure 5 (a)); Ge II with one solenidion (σ) ( Figure 5 (b)); Ge III without solenidia ( Figure 5 (c)); Ta I and II each with subterminal eupathidium (ζ) ( Figure 5 (a,b)). Deutonymph and adult are unknown.

caption.paragraph: Table 1. Standard measurements (in µm) of the new species described in the present study. H = holotype; P = paratype.

caption.paragraph: Table 3. Standard measurements (in µm) of the new species described in the present study. H = holotype; P = paratype.

paragraph.tableNote: Abbreviations: I = σ I, σ II, σ III = length of the solenidia on Genu I–III; Κ I, Κ II = length of microseta on Genu I, Tibia I and Genu II; φ’ I, φ” I = length of the solenidia on Tibia I; ω I = length of solenidion on Tarsus I; Ε I = length of famulus on Tarsus I; ζ’ I = length of dorsal eupathidium on Tarsus I; ζ I = length of subterminal eupathidium on Tarsus I; φ’ II, φ” II = length of the solenidia on Tibia II; ω II = length of solenidion on Tarsus II; Ε II = length of famulus on Tarsus II; ζ II = length of subterminal eupathidium on Tarsus II; φ III = length of the solenidia on Tibia III; ω III = length of solenidion on Tarsus III.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 2.
Caramuruacarus carnavalesca Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : (a) dorsal view of gnathosoma; (b) ventral view of palp. Abbreviations: ω = solenidion on palptarsus; bs = subcapitular setae; cs = adoral setae; Odo = odontus. Scale bar: 50 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The new genus is named in honour of the epic poem ‘Caramuru’ that exalts Brazilian lands, combined with the word ‘acarus’, which means ‘mite’ in Latin. Gender masculine.

Differential diagnosis.
Caramuruacarus Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
gen. nov. is similar to
Akodonacarus Goff and Webb, 1989
,
Hannemania Oudemans, 1911
,
Leeuwenhoekia Oudemans, 1911
,
Mastalacarus Goff and Lukoschus, 1983
,
Morelacarus VercammenGrandjean, 1973
and
Xenodontacarus Loomis and Goff, 1973
in having five-branched setae on the palptarsus. The new genus differs from
Akodonacarus
,
Hannemania
,
Leeuwenhoekia
,
Morelacarus
and
Xenodontacarus
by having only one side of the cheliceral blade with a row of teeth ( Figure 1 (a)), and four-pronged odontus ( Figure 2 (a)), while the other genera mentioned above differ by having dorsal and ventral rows of teeth and two or three prongs on the odontus. Furthermore,
Caramuruacarus Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
gen. nov. differs from
Akodonacarus
by the absence of dorsal eupathidium on Ta I and σ on Ge III – Figure 5 (a,b) (vs present); from
Hannemania
by having two σ on Ge I – Figure 5 (a) (vs multiples) and absence of σ on Ge III – Figure 5 (c) (vs multiples); from
Leeuwenhoekia
by the absence of the ζ on the palptarsus – Figure 2 (b) (vs present); from
Mastalacarus
by having two σ on Ge I – Figure 5 (a) (vs one σ), and the absence of σ on Ge III – Figure 5 (c) (vs present); from
Morelacarus
by having two σ on Ge I – Figure 5 (a) (vs one σ), and the presence of σ on Ge II – Figure 5 (b) (vs absent); and from
Xenodontacarus
by having the σ on Ge II – Figure 4 (b) (vs absent) and claws and claw-like empodium without onychotriches – Figure 5 (vs with onychotriches).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 3.
Caramuruacarus carnavalesca Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : prodorsal sclerite. Open circles = ornamentations of the prodorsal sclerite. Abbreviations: se = external scapular setae; si = internal scapular setae (trichobothria); ve = external vertical setae; vi = internal vertical setae. Scale bar: 20 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Larva ( holotype ). Gnathosoma – fPp = B/B/BNB/5Bω; odontus tetrafurcate; cheliceral blade with tricuspid cap and the ventral side with ventral row of large blunt of 8 to 10 teeth; gnathobase punctate, subcapitular ( bs ) and adoral ( cs ) setae branched ( Figure 2 (a,b)). Idiosoma – eyes present, 2/2, set in ocular plate, anterior lens larger; prodorsal sclerite with sparse punctations ( Figures 3 , 10 (a)), anterior margin slightly sinuous with nasus, lateral and posterior margins concave; with pair of nude flagelliform trichobothria ( si ), and four slightly expanded setae [pair of ve (= AL) setae and pair of vi (= AM) setae] plus a pair of expanded and leaflike se (= PL) setae, with long and triangular setules; se > si > vi ≥ ve ; tracheae and stigma absent; opisthosoma ( Figure 4 (a,b)) with a total of 91 setae, dorsal opisthosoma with 46 setae, C row with 16 setae, D and E rows with eight setae each, F row with six setae and H row with eight setae irregularly placed, and 45 ventral opisthosomal setae (22 setae anterior to the anus and 23 posterior setae). Dorsal and lateral ventral opisthosomal setae expanded and modified, leaflike, like se setae ( Figure 10 (b,c)); One pair of sternal setae ( 3a ) between coxal fields III. Legs – femur of legs I–III not divided into basifemur and telofemur, each leg terminates with pair of claws and claw-like empodium without onychotriches, coxal fields punctate; Leg I – coxal field setae 1a and 1b branched (2B); trochanter 1B; femur 6B; genu 4B, 2 σ and Κ; tibia 8B, 2 φ and Κ; tarsus 23B with ω, ε, and subterminal eupathidium (ζ), base of famulus (ε) distal to solenidion (ω) ( Figure 5 (a)). Leg II – coxal field seta 2b (1B); trochanter 1B; femur 5B; genu 4B, σ and Κ; tibia 6B, 2 φ; tarsus 16B with ω, ε and subterminal eupathidium (ζ), base of ε proximal to ω ( Figure 5 (b)). Leg III – coxal field seta 3b (1B) in distal position; trochanter 1B; femur 4B; genu 4B, tibia 6B, φ; tarsus 15B ( Figure 5 (c)).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 4.
Caramuruacarus carnavalesca Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : (a) dorsal view of idiosoma; (b) ventral view of idiosoma. Solid circles = ventral setae; open circles = dorsal setae. Abbreviations:
d 1 –d 4
= D row setae;
e 1 –e 4
= E row setae;
f 1 –f 3
= F row setae; 1a = anterior sternal setae inside coxal field I; 1b = coxal field I seta; 2b = coxal field II seta; 3a = posterior sternal setae; 3b = coxal field III seta. Scale bars: 100 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype .
Larva , Cave CH-25 , Santa Rita de Ouro Preto , Minas Gerais State , Brazil , ( 20.552° S , 43.514°W );
28–30 April 2009
; on the soil ; F. Pellegatti et al. coll.; deposited as IBSP 15693 .
Etymology. The
specific name ‘carnavalesca’ (adjective related to Carnaval) refers to the extravagance of the dorsal opisthosomal setae, se setae and some ventral setae that recall the costumes of the Carnaval – a traditional Brazilian festival.

bibRefCitation.author: Wharton GW
bibRefCitation.refString: Wharton GW. 1938. Acarina of Yucatan caves. Carnegie Instit Wash. 491: 137 - 152.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Palpfemur and palpgenu each with single branched seta ( Figure 6 (a)); dorsal and ventral setae branched and lateral setae nude on the palptibia ( Figure 6 (a,b)); adoral ( cs ) setae branched ( Figure 6 (a)); odontus multifurcate with the apex dividing into five or six prongs, plus two other larger supplementary prongs in the middle of the odontus ( Figures 6 (a,b), 10(f)); nude flagelliform trichobothria ( si ) ( Figures 7 , 10 (d)); C and D rows with 12 irregularly placed setae each ( Figure 8 (a)); E row with eight setae ( Figure 8 (a)); F row with six setae ( Figure 8 (a)); H row with four setae ( Figure 8 (a)); total opisthosomal setae 42 including 48 to 50 ventral setae ( Figure 8 (a,b)); base of famulus (ε) on Ta I and II proximal to solenidion (ω) ( Figure 9 (a,b)).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 6.
Whartonia parauapebensis Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : (a) dorsal view of gnathosoma; (b) ventral view of palp. Abbreviations: ω = solenidion on palptarsus; ζ = subterminal eupathidium of palptarsus; bs = subcapitular setae; cs = adoral setae; Odo = odontus. Scale bar: 50 μm.

Figure 7.
Whartonia parauapebensis Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : prodorsal sclerite. Open circles = ornamentations of the prodorsal sclerite. Abbreviations: se = external scapular setae; si = internal scapular setae (trichobothria); ve = external vertical setae; vi = internal vertical setae. Scale bar: 20 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Larva ( holotype and one paratype ). Gnathosoma – fPp = B/B/BNB/7Bωζ; odontus multifurcate with the apex dividing into five or six prongs, plus two other larger supplementary prongs in the middle of the odontus ( Figure 10 (f)); cheliceral blade with ventral row of large blunt teeth and dorso-lateral row of small pointed teeth bordering the apical cap (more than 15 teeth each side); gnathobase punctate, subcapitular ( bs ) and adoral ( cs ) setae branched ( Figure 6 (a,b)). Idiosoma – eyes present, 2/2, set in ocular plate, anterior lens larger; rectangular prodorsal sclerite sparsely punctate, punctuation mostly concentrated in the lateral regions ( Figures 7 , 10 (d)), anterior margin slightly sinuous with anterolateral shoulders, lateral margins slightly concave and posterior margin biconvex; with pair of nude flagelliform trichobothria ( si ), and six normal, branched setae [pair of ve (= AL) setae, pair of se (= PL) setae, and pair of vi (= AM) setae]; si > vi > se > ve ; tracheae and stigma absent. Opisthosoma ( Figure 8 (a,b)) with a total of 90 to 92 setae entire covered with setules, dorsal opisthosoma ( Figure 10 (e)) with 42 setae, C and D rows with 12 irregularly placed setae, E row with eight setae, F row with six setae and H row with four setae, and 48 to 50 ventral opisthosomal setae (17 setae anterior to the anus and 31 to 33 posterior setae). One pair of sternal setae ( 3a ) between coxal fields III. Legs – femur of legs I–III entire (not divided into basifemur and telofemur), each leg terminates in a pair of claws and claw-like empodium without onychotriches, coxal fields punctate; Leg I – coxal field setae 1a and 1b branched (2B); trochanter 1B; femur 6B; genu 4B, 2 σ and a long Κ; tibia 8B, 2 φ and a long Κ; tarsus 37B to 38B with ω, ε, dorsal eupathidium (ζ’) and subterminal eupathidium (ζ), base of famulus (ε) proximal to solenidion (ω) ( Figure 9 (a)). Leg II – coxal field seta 2b (1B); trochanter 1B; femur 5B; genu 4B, σ and a long Κ; tibia 6B, 2 φ; tarsus 28B with ω, ε and a subterminal eupathidium (ζ), base of ε proximal to ω ( Figure 9 (b)). Leg III – coxal field setae 3b and 3c (2B); trochanter 1B; femur 4B; genu 4B, σ, tibia 6B, φ; tarsus 26B to 28B with ω ( Figure 9 (c)).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 10. Phase contrast images of the new leeuwenhoekiid mites.
Caramuruacarus carnavalesca Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : (a) prodorsal sclerite; (b) dorsal ophistosomal setae; (c) distal dorsal ophistosomal setae.
Whartonia parauapebensis Bassini-Silva and Jacinavicius
sp. nov. : (d) prodorsal sclerite; (e) dorsal ophistosomal seteae; (f) palp and gnathosoma with the chelicerae. The black arrow indicates two larger supplementary prongs in the middle of the odontus. Abbreviations: se = external scapular setae; si = internal scapular setae (trichobothria); ve = external vertical setae; vi = internal vertical setae. Scale bars: 20 μm.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype .
Larva, Cave N 3-047, Parauapebas, Pará State , Brazil , ( 6.040°S , 50.227°W );
3–17 April 2013
; on the cave soil; F. V . Freitas et al. coll.; deposited as IBSP14143 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype .
One larva, same locality and date; deposited as IBSP14151
.
The specific name ‘parauapebensis’ is in honour of the type locality – Parauapebas Municipality.

Whartonia parauapebensis
sp. nov. is similar to
Whartonia nudosetosa ( Wharton, 1938 )
and
Whartonia pachywhartoni Vercammen-Grandjean, 1966
, as they share the following characteristics – absence of companion seta (z) on Ta I; Cx III bisetose; and presence of ω on Ta III. However, the new species differs from the other two species by having the following characters: lateral palptibial seta nude ( Figure 6 (a)); and the odontus with two larger supplementary prongs in the middle ( Figure 6 (a)). Furthermore, the new species has two pair of eyes set in ocular plates, while
W. nudosetosa
does not have an ocular plate. Also,
Whartonia parauapebensis
sp. nov. has fewer opisthosomal setae than
W. pachywhartoni
(90 to 92 setae vs 148 setae).

subSection.paragraph:
Nielsen et al. (2021) listed four subgenera for
Whartonia
as follows:
Asolentria VercammenGrandjean, 1968
;
Brennanella Radford, 1954
; Fascutonia Vercammen-Grandjean, Langston and Audy, 1973 and
Whartonia
s.s. Ewing, 1944.

The genus
Brennanella Radford, 1954
, based on
B. longispina Radford
, was synonymised with
Whartonia
by Domrow (1962) based mainly on Radford’s incorrect interpretation of the leg femora as divided. Vercammen-Grandjean et al. (1965) redescribed
B. longispina
and placed
Brennanella
as a subgenus of
Whartonia
, and VercammenGrandjean (1971) listed three species in
Brennanella –
B. carpenteri Brennan
,
B. longispina
, and
B. scarcella Vercammen-Grandjean. Takahashi et al. (2006)
and Zajkowska et al. (2018) followed Domrow (1962) . On the other hand, Nielsen et al. (2021) listed
Brennanella
as a subgenus of
Whartonia
without comment, and also listed
W. scarcella
and
W. carpenteri
in the subgenus
Whartonia
. In the present study, we follow Takahashi et al. (2006) and Zajkowska et al. (2018) and consider
Brennanella
synonymous with
Whartonia
.

The other three subgenera (
Asolentria , Fascutonia
and
Whartonia
s.s. ) are distinguished by the following characteristics:
Whartonia
s.s. is differentiated from the other two by having the coxal field III bisetose, no z seta on the tarsus of leg I, and a ω on the tarsus of leg III .
Asolentria
has a unisetose coxal field III , a z seta present on the tarsus of leg I, and no ω on the tarsus of leg III . Fascutonia is distinguished from the other two subgenera by having a normal femoral seta count of 6-6-5 for legs I– III , respectively, compared to 6-5- 4 in the other subgenera. While the numbers of normal setae on the femora are stable in most taxa, we have observed variations between the right and left legs in the same specimen. We suggest a review of all
Whartonia
types is needed to build a data set that can either support or reject the current subgenera for
Whartonia
.

With the description of this new genus and two new species, the number of Brazilian Leeuwenhoekiidae has increased to six genera and 12 species, including three species of
Whartonia
.

We thank Debra Creel, Andrew Ulsamer (SEL-USDA), Armando Rosario-Lebron (APHIS-USDA), the Smithsonian Natural History Museum and National Agricultural Library (NAL-USDA), and Gabrielle Ribeiro de Andrade, Maria Cristina Ferreira do Rosário, Valeria Castilho Onofrio (LCZ-IBu), for their help with references, technical support, and providing access to the IBSP collection. We also thank the collection of the ‘Carste Ciência e Meio Ambiente’, which provided us the photographs of the mite collection sites described above.
